title: The Sustainability of Open Education at Community Colleges
segmentation: I'm going to talk with you about the California Open Textbook Project, so this is a project that involves our three public higher education systems, the University of California, the California State University, and the Community colleges, and that has the opportunity to to affect our 3 million students that are enrolled within that.
System so this mandate came from our textbook.
I mean sorry from our legislature.

It was an initiative introduced in 2011, but it had been kind of boiling around for awhile and it was really meant to address the rising cost of education and students, particularly who had been affected by the recession.
The worldwide recession, which had caused a cutback in funding to institutions.
an A rise in tuition and costs of material.
So there were two state bills that were introduced.
A one was to establish a faculty council to identify the top 50 college courses and to establish a peer review process for open educational resources that could be used in those courses.
And the second piece was establishing a ovr repository of these curated resources that will be highly available to California faculty and students.
But they.
Had a unique funding model, so the legislation mandated that the state of California would provide up to $5,000,000 for this effort, but no money would be allocated without matching funds.
And so the legislation itself passed in 2011, but in fact it was almost a year later.
I'm sorry.

In 2012 it was almost a year later when when we found a funder so that the project has been underway now for about six months Ann is making progress and I want to thank the Hewlett Foundation for being that that special Angel that funded the start of the California Textbook Project.
Current status we're working on identifying those 50 courses.
I think those are in place now are really a key piece, of course, is articulation between the systems 'cause we're talking about.
The college is the first 2 year Division, the 1st, the 1st two years of college and moving into the University.
Peer review process is going on and we're recruiting faculty right now for that.
An faculty and students have been surveyed about their needs for O ER.

And a really big piece of this is that we're featuring faculty who have adopted O ER, we're building eportfolios with them in tutorials, because what we hear from faculty who have not yet embrace to ER is, well.
How do I do that?
And we've found from doing workshops with them that faculty learn best from other faculty who've already done that, and so we have a big emphasis on OE portfolios.
And now very quickly I'm going to switch to the national view.
So we've.
This also came out in about the same time frame 2011 as we were still in recovery from the recession.
An our Department of Labor decided to create a grant that was focused on Community College retraining for workforce development.
Very exciting project was also addressing not only the recession but sort of the global change in what workforce looks like today.

So as you know, in the United States we had many manufacturing jobs that went away in the last 20 years, and so people who worked in manufacturing either had to go into very low pain, non skilled jobs or.
Or essentially they had to change careers and so this was really meant to address that issue.
And the nice thing was it was focused on the colleges.
So these are.

These are generally one to two year certificates and the Department of Labor allocated 2 billion dollars over four years and we're just coming to the completion of our of our first wave of those programs, so we will be seeing some interesting stuff shortly.
And the idea behind these training certificates were that they would lead to living wage jobs for those who have been outsourced, whose jobs have been outsourced an whose skills have been obsoleted.
The primary.
My glasses here just to let you know the primary areas that that the development is in was basic skills, which is what we call bridging skills to get into University.
Also, healthcare, manufacturing, energy transportation and information technology.
So all growing sectors where we believe Jobs will continue to grow into the 21st century.

The really wonderful thing was that the Department of Labor working with the Department of Education decided to make all curriculum developed through this grant openly licensed, which means this is freely available to faculty and students at other colleges to develop their own programs and maximize.
Impact, so the current status as I mentioned is that first wave that went out in 2011 is coming to completion this fall, so we'll see a lot of new materials available shortly.
The last wave of the grant will be allocated this fall, so the very fourth set of folks will start off on their projects this fall.
We were still looking for an O ER repository.
The last time I checked, so there is still work to be done, but it's a very very positive outcome.
Ann, I were going to turn this over now to questions from.
